title: 104_hr3048
content: The Act may be cited as the "Regulatory Flexibility Amendments Act of 1996". Judicial review is addressed in the Act. Section 611 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to allow small entities to petition for judicial review of final rules that were certified to have no significant economic impact or had a regulatory flexibility analysis prepared. A court with jurisdiction over rule compliance can review the certification or analysis. A court with jurisdiction can review the certification or analysis of final rules affecting small entities. The term 'affected small entity' refers to those adversely impacted by the rule. This subsection does not affect a court's authority to delay the effective date of a rule under other laws. The final rule does not affect a court's authority to delay the effective date of a rule. The court can review the certification or analysis of final rules impacting small entities and order corrective action if necessary. The court can order corrective action if the final regulatory flexibility analysis was not prepared properly. If the agency fails to comply within 90 days, the court may stay the rule or provide other appropriate relief, considering the rule of prejudicial error. The court can order corrective action if the final regulatory flexibility analysis was not prepared properly, considering the rule of prejudicial error. In an action for judicial review of a rule, the regulatory flexibility analysis shall be part of the record. Judicial review of any other impact statement required by law is not barred. The amendment applies to final agency rules issued after the enactment date. SEC. 3. RULES COMMENTED ON BY SBA CHIEF COUNSEL FOR ADVOCACY. Section 612 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to require agencies to transmit proposed rules and initial regulatory flexibility analysis to the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration before publication. The amended Section 612 of title 5, US Code requires agencies to send proposed rules and initial regulatory flexibility analysis to the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration. The Chief Counsel may provide a statement on the rule's impact on small entities, which the agency must publish along with their response. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy must review proposed rules and provide a statement on their impact on small entities. The agency must publish this statement and their response in the Federal Register when issuing general notice of the proposed rule. Special rules apply to certain agencies regarding monetary policy and safety of federally insured depository institutions. The Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, in connection with monetary policy or ensuring the safety of federally insured depository institutions, affiliates, credit unions, or government sponsored housing enterprises, is exempt from certain requirements. Section 603(a) of title 5, United States Code, is amended accordingly. Congress believes that the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration should have the ability to appear as amicus curiae in court cases reviewing rules.
